leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,095] r 2.1 Title of documents in a proceeding — Form 1

leg:heading.title: Title of documents in a proceeding — Form 1

p.text: The title of a document filed in a proceeding must be in accordance with Form 1 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,100] r 2.2 Originating process and interlocutory process — Forms 2 and 3

leg:heading.title: Originating process and interlocutory process — Forms 2 and 3

p.text: Unless these Rules otherwise provide, a person must make an application required or permitted by the Corporations Act to be made to the Court:
if the application is not made in a proceeding already commenced in the Court — by filing an originating process; and
in any other case, and whether interlocutory relief or final relief is claimed — by filing an interlocutory process.
[subr (1) am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004 ; Gaz 77 of 24 June 2005 p 3080, effective 24 June 2005]

Unless the Court otherwise directs, a person may make an application to the Court in relation to a proceeding in respect of which final relief has been granted by filing an interlocutory process in that proceeding.
An originating process must:
be in accordance with Form 2 ; and
state:
each section of the Corporations Act or the ASIC Act , or each regulation of the Corporations Regulations, under which the proceeding is brought; and
the relief sought.
[subr (3) am Gaz 168 of 22 December 2000 p 13608 ; Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
An interlocutory process must:
be in accordance with Form 3 ; and
state:
if appropriate, each section of the Corporations Act or the ASIC Act , or each regulation of the Corporations Regulations, or each rule of Court under which the application is made; and
the relief sought.

In an application for winding up in insolvency on the ground that the company has failed to comply with a statutory demand, the applicant should consider completing Part C of Form 2 as shown in Schedule 2 (Notes to these Rules).
[subr (4) am Gaz 168 of 22 December 2000 p 13608 ; Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004 ; Gaz 48 of 5 April 2007 p 2118, effective 5 April 2007]
Legislation cited in [15,100.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 467A.

Multiple creditors cannot join together as co-plaintiffs in winding up proceedings: Australian Macfarms Pty Ltd v Confucius (NSW) Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Santow J, 22 May 1998, unreported); First Line Distribution Pty Ltd v Whiley (1995) 18 ACSR 185; 13 ACLC 1216; BC9505407 . But a winding up application made jointly by creditors is an irregularity for the purpose of s 467A of the Corporations Act 2001 and may be corrected by an amendment deleting the surplus plaintiffs, unless the joinder has caused, or is likely to cause, substantial injustice: Australian Macfarms Pty Ltd v Confucius (NSW) Pty Ltd, above.
Legislation cited in [15,100.7] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 588M.

A cause of action wholly pursuant to s 588M of the Corporations Act should be commenced by originating process and not by statement of claim: Wily v King [2010] NSWSC 352; BC201002510 at [18]-[28] per Barrett J.
Legislation cited in [15,100.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 471B, s 500(2).

The requirement for leave, to proceed or commence proceedings, pursuant to s 471B Corporations Act 2001 (for a wounding up in insolvency or by the Court) or s 500(2) Corporations Act 2001 (for a voluntary winding up) was imposed to prevent the harassment of a company in liquidation and the waste of its assets by litigation: Re AJ Benjamin Ltd (in liq) [1969] 2 NSWR 374; (1969) 90 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 107 . An applicant must show a prima facie case and that there is no procedural or substantive prejudice to the creditors in the winding up if leave is granted: Thomson v Mulgoa Irrigation Co Ltd (1983) 4 BC (NSW) 33; McLean v Burns Philp Trustee Co Pty Ltd (1985) 2 NSWLR 623; 9 ACLR 926 . Leave may be granted subject to terms: Re WA Brown & Sons Pty Ltd [1964] NSWR 575; (1964) 81 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 402 (including undertakings as to the enforcement of any judgment). Failure to obtain leave does not vitiate the proceedings it merely makes the plaintiff liable in costs: Martin v AJ & KR McKenna Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Young J, 12 May 1987, unreported, BC8701378).
Legislation cited in [15,100.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 500(2).

Whether an appeal against a decision in favour of a company in liquidation requires leave to proceed (under Corporations Act 2001 s 500(2) ) is unclear: Bevillesta Pty Ltd v D Tannous No 2 Pty Ltd [2010] NSWCA 277; BC201007919 at [7]–[10] compare Distinctive FX 9 Pty Ltd v Statewide Developments Pty Ltd [2012] NSWCA 393; BC201209455 at [13] . If leave is required, and appropriate to provide, it may be granted retrospectively: Ingot Capital Investments Pty Ltd v Macquarie Equity Capital Markets Ltd [2007] NSWCA 338; BC200710218 at [20]–[21] per Giles JA (extension of time for filing cross-appeal refused).

level.toc-caption: [15,100.20] Processes under the Corporations Rules and pleadings

p.text: Legislation cited in [15,100.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999 r 2.2(1)(b).

heading.title: Processes under the Corporations Rules and pleadings

p.text: The concepts of originating and interlocutory process differ between the Corporations Rules and the UCPR. Where the Corporations Rules apply (i) all claims for relief, including final relief, are required to be made by interlocutory process: r 2.2(1)(b) ; and (ii) neither originating nor interlocutory process is to be used as a pleading, as distinct from a document in which relief is claimed. Any application for pleadings in proceedings that are subject to the Corporations Rules should be made either in the originating process or in a subsequent interlocutory process. An originating or interlocutory process should not be amended so as to be converted into a pleading. If the court determines that pleading is appropriate it will normally make an order that the proceedings proceed on pleadings and give a direction for the filing of a statement of claim: eg. Edenden v Bignell [2008] NSWSC 666; BC200805131 at [31]–[34] per Barrett J (originating process ordered to be struck out except as to the relief sought, the matter to proceed on pleadings and stand dismissed if statement of claim not filed and served within a certain time). In accordance with this rule, an interlocutory process may be used in relation to a proceeding where final relief has been granted, even by applicants who were not parties to the initial proceedings: Re Weston Application; Employers Mutual Indemnity (Workers Compensation) Ltd v Omni Corp Pty Ltd (2009) 255 ALR 362; [2009] NSWSC 264; BC200902335 at [19]–[25] per Barrett J.
On receiving an originating process or interlocutory process, the Registrar:
must fix a time, date and place for hearing and endorse those details on the originating process or interlocutory process; and
may seal a sufficient number of copies for service and proof of service.
[subr (2) am Gaz 93 of 1 June 2001 p 3023]
Unless the Court otherwise directs, an originating process, or interlocutory process, must be supported by an affidavit stating the facts in support of the process.

Subject to rule 2.4A, an affidavit in support of an originating process must annex or exhibit a record of a search of the records maintained by ASIC, in relation to the company that is the subject of the application to which the originating process relates, carried out no earlier than 7 days before the originating process is filed.
An example of the affidavit in support of an application for winding up in insolvency for failure to comply with a statutory demand is shown in Schedule 2 (Notes to these Rules).
[subr (2) am Gaz 53 of 16 May 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 16 May 2008]
[r 2.4 am Gaz 93 of 1 June 2001 p 3023]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,115] r 2.4A Application for order setting aside statutory demand (Corporations Act s 459G)

leg:heading.title: Application for order setting aside statutory demand (Corporations Act s 459G)

p.text: This rule applies, and subrule 2.4(2) does not apply, to an application by a company under section 459G of the Corporations Act for an order setting aside a statutory demand served on the company.
[subr (1) am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
The plaintiff may file with the originating process seeking the order a copy of the statutory demand and a copy of any affidavit that accompanied the statutory demand.
The plaintiff must:

no earlier than 7 days before the originating process is filed, and not later than the day before the hearing of the application, carry out a search of the records maintained by ASIC in relation to the plaintiff; and
either:
annex the record of the search to the affidavit in support of the originating process; or
file the record of the search before, or tender it on, the hearing of the application.
[subr (3) am Gaz 53 of 16 May 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 16 May 2008]
[r 2.4A insrt Gaz 93 of 1 June 2001 p 3023 ; am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
Legislation cited in [15,115.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 459E(2)(e), s 459E(3), s 459J.
(CTH) Corporations Regulations 2001 Form 509H.
(NSW) Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999 [15,345].

The prescribed form of a creditor's demand under s 459E(2)(e) of the Corporations Act 2001 is Form 509H in Schedule 2 to the Corporations Regulations. The statutory definition of “statutory demand” includes a document which purports to be a statutory demand. If a document “purports to be” a statutory demand, the power of the Court to set it aside on the basis that there is a defect in or relating to the demand, is determined by s 459J : Spencer Constructions Pty Ltd v G & M Aldridge Pty Ltd (1997) 76 FCR 452 at 459; 147 ALR 444; [1997] FCA 681; BC9703300 , Fed C of A, Full Court. Unless the debt, or each of the debts, is a judgment debt, the demand must be accompanied by an affidavit that:
verifies that the debt, or the total of the amounts of the debts, is due and payable by the company; and
complies with the rules: s 459E(3) Corporations Act 2001. See [15,345] .

A statutory demand can only be issued in relation to debts that are due and payable at the date of the demand. Contingent or prospective liabilities cannot be the subject of a demand, nor can an unresolved claim for unliquidated damages: First Line Distribution Pty Ltd v Whiley (1995) 18 ACSR 185 at 188; 13 ACLC 1216; BC9505407 . A joint debt gives rise to one indivisible cause of action: Duck v Mayeu [1892] 2 QB 511 at 513; [1891–4] All ER Rep 410 . The prescribed form does not make provision for naming two or more persons as the debtors liable to pay a joint debt. A creditor cannot change the nature of a joint debt by demanding of each debtor that it pay half of it: Hills Motorway Ltd v UBS AG [2005] NSWSC 1086; BC200508993 at [31] [33] per White J (two demands for half the debt each were served on parties jointly liable for the debt).

level.toc-caption: [15,115.12] Debts subject to stay of enforcement

heading.title: Debts subject to stay of enforcement

p.text: A stay or an order restraining the enforcement of a judgment debt does not alter the “due and payable” status of the debt. Australian Beverage Distributors Pty Ltd v Evans & Tate Premium Wines Pty Ltd (2007) 61 ACSR 441; [2007] NSWCA 57; BC200701811 at [26]–[35], [40]–[41] per Beazley JA, Hodgson and Santow JJA agreeing (a stay of an assessed costs order did not affect the existence of the debt) citing In Re Pollack; Ex parte Deputy Commissioner of Taxation (1991) 32 FCR 40 at 51, 56; (1991) 103 ALR 133 ; (bankruptcy petition — stay did not preclude operation of judgment — special statutory provisions precluding payment by instalments); Re Brent Hughes; Ex parte Westpac Banking Corporation [1997] FCA 1324 Merkel J; BC9706380 at pp 4–5 (bankruptcy petition — application for substitution as petitioning creditor — judgment stayed pending appeal). However, if there is an operative stay the court retains a discretion to stay the proceedings until the debt proceedings have been completely resolved: Australian Beverage Distributors Pty Ltd v Evans & Tate Premium Wines Pty Ltd (2007) 61 ACSR 441; [2007] NSWCA 57; BC200701811 ; Scope Data Systems Pty Ltd v BDO Nelson Parkhill (2003) 199 ALR 56; [2003] NSWSC 137; BC200300885 at [26] (statutory stay pending appeal — inappropriate to order winding up whilst stay operated).

level.toc-caption: [15,115.13] Debts the subject of a stayed judgment

heading.title: Debts the subject of a stayed judgment

p.text: There is a conceptual distinction between a stay of a judgment itself and a stay of proceedings to enforce the judgment: Alam v Quest Enterprises [2006] NSWSC 752; BC200605735 White J at [30] ; Re Brent Hughes; Ex parte Westpac Banking Corporation [1997] FCA 1324 Merkel J; BC9706380 at 6 . A stay of the judgment postpones its legal effect: In the Marriage of Clemett (1980) 50 FLR 248 (stay of an order for custody — regulations permitted the court to not merely stay execution but also stay the substantive operation of the order); Future Graphics Pty Ltd v Fullpoint Pty Ltd (1990) 8 ACLC 700 at 703; BC9002321 (stay of District Court judgment held to be effective to prevent deemed insolvency arising from a failure to pay a statutory demand). On the other hand a stay of proceedings to enforce a judgment still permits recognition of its legal effect in determining the rights of the parties: see Australian Beverage Distributors Pty Ltd v Evans & Tate Premium Wines Pty Ltd (2007) 61 ACSR 441; [2007] NSWCA 57; BC200701811 ; Clifton Securities Ltd v Huntley [1948] 2 All ER 283 at 284 per Denning J (stay of judgment for possession of leased premises — lessees right to possession terminated — unable to claim damages for disruption of utilities).

level.toc-caption: [15,115.15] Application to set aside a demand

p.text: Legislation cited in [15,115.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 459E, s 459G(1), s 459G(2), s 459G(3).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 35.6(6).

heading.title: Application to set aside a demand

p.text: A company that has been served with a statutory demand under s 459E of the Corporations Act 2001 may apply under s 459G(1) for an order setting aside the demand. The application can only be made within 21 days: s 459G(2) . The court cannot extend the time: David Grant & Co Pty Ltd v Westpac Banking Corp (1995) 184 CLR 265; 131 ALR 353; [1995] HCA 43 ; and ought not grant a stay: Ketrim Pty Ltd v Jaeger Corp Pty Ltd (2003) 21 ACLC 8; [2002] NSWSC 871; BC200206007 . An application under s 459G is made by filing and serving on the person who served the demand, a copy of the application together with an affidavit supporting the application: s 459G(3) . The onus is on the company to satisfy the court either that there is a genuine dispute about the existence, or the amount, of the debt to which the demand relates, or that the company has an offsetting claim. Failure to serve exhibits to the supporting affidavit within the 21 day period (see s 459G(3)) is not necessarily fatal to the application see: Tatlers.com.au Pty Ltd v Davis (2007) 25 ACLC 1150; [2007] NSWSC 835 at [8]–[23] per White J (finding that “affidavit” does not include an exhibit and distinguishing the terms of r 35.6(6) UCPR from O 14 r 4(3) Federal Court Rules and the decision in Kortz Ltd v Data Acquisition Pty Ltd (2006) 155 FCR 556; [2006] FCA 1722; BC200610302 ). A demand based on the unpaid balance of a judgment debt (or for a sum different from the sum in the judgment) must be accompanied by an affidavit for the purposes s 459G(3): Anderson Formrite Pty Ltd v CASC Hire Pty Ltd (2005) 147 FCR 379 at 391–392 [63]; [2005] FCA 1424; BC200507649 (demand set aside). It is not mandatory that the supporting affidavit annex the statutory demand sought to be set aside: Tatlers.com.au Pty Ltd v Davis [2007] NSWSC 835; BC200706183 at [31] per White J (the supporting affidavit did not annex the demand – not fatal). However, the applicant must prove the existence of the demand: Expressway Spares Pty Ltd v CTK Engineering Pty Ltd [2005] NSWSC 1200; BC200510141 at [3] .

The rules allowing substitution of parties cover not only cases of misnomer, clerical error and misdescription but also where the plaintiff, intending to sue a person identified by a particular description, was mistaken as to the name of the person who answered that description: Bridge Shipping Pty Ltd v Grand Shipping SA (1991) 173 CLR 231; 103 ALR 607; BC9102619 . Amendment of application to set aside a statutory demand are relatively freely allowed in cases of misnomer: A & M Short Pty Ltd v Prestige Residential Marketing Pty Ltd (2005) 54 ACSR 760; [2005] NSWSC 872; BC200506430 at [31] . The applicant should adduce some evidence as to how the mistake came about, and the drafter’s intentions as to which party was to sue. Use of a wrong ACN number will not necessarily preclude amendment. Where the amendment is permitted the action is treated as if it originally named the substituted person and there is a mere correction of the misnomer: A & M Short Pty Ltd v Prestige Residential Marketing Pty Ltd, above .

level.toc-caption: [15,115.25] Affidavits must raise the grounds relied upon

p.text: Legislation cited in [15,115.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 459G, s 459J(1)(a).

heading.title: Affidavits must raise the grounds relied upon

p.text: The application to set aside a statutory demand must be supported by affidavits filed within 21 days after service of the demand.

Whether a document is, for the purposes of Corporations Act 2001 s 459G , an “affidavit” is a question to be determined according to the law of New South Wales: Fastlink Calling Pty Ltd v Macquarie Telecom Pty Ltd (2008) 26 ACLC 374; [2008] NSWSC 299; BC200802264 at [14] per Barrett J. The affidavit served need not be a precise “reproduction” or “duplicate” or "exact copy" or “photographic copy” — provided a complete and accurate transcript of the contents of the affidavit has been provided: Medeco Group Pty Ltd v Cripps [2009] NSWSC 927; BC200908221 at [12]–[21] per White J (a facsimile copy of the affidavit was missing a line of text, and a subsequent email copy was missing signatures — but overall a complete copy of the affidavit was received).

The requirement for a “supporting” affidavit is satisfied if the affidavit has the effect of raising the basis for the dispute. The affidavit will comply with that requirement if the supporting grounds can be identified either in the body of the affidavit or from the contents of documents annexed to the affidavit: Saferack Pty Ltd v Marketing Heads Australia Pty Ltd (2007) 25 ACLC 1392; [2007] NSWSC 1143; BC200708777 at [25] . The affidavit will also comply if it identifies the grounds of dispute by available (as distinct from necessary) inference: Graywinter Properties Pty Ltd v Gas & Fuel Corporation Superannuation Fund (1996) 70 FCR 452; 21 ACSR 581; BC9604587 ; Hansmar Investments Pty Ltd v Perpetual Trustee Co Ltd (2007) 61 ACSR 321; [2007] NSWSC 103; BC200701052 at [26]–[34] per White J (not following Process Machinery Australia Pty Ltd (t/as DCL Engineering) v ACN 057 260 590 [2002] NSWSC 45; BC200200222 at [22] per Barrett J; Elm Financial Services Pty Ltd v MacDougal [2004] NSWSC 560; BC200403857 at [7] per Barrett J).

A genuine dispute depending upon a matter of law must also be identified, either expressly or by inference, in the supporting affidavit filed within time: Tatlers.com.au Pty Ltd v Davis (2007) 25 ACLC 1150; [2007] NSWSC 835; BC200706183 at [25]–[28] per White J (explaining Callite Pty Ltd v Adams [2001] NSWSC 52; BC200100316 per Santow J and Michael Davies Associates Pty Ltd v Wollacott Hale Corlett & Jumikis Consulting Engineers Pty Ltd [2002] NSWSC 472; BC200202794 at [14] per Macready M).

If it is not raised by the supporting affidavit, a ground of opposition to the demand if not raised by the supporting affidavit may not be relied upon, even if it should have been reasonably apparent to the defendant from what has passed between the parties: Tatlers.com.au Pty Ltd v Davis (2007) 25 ACLC 1150; [2007] NSWSC 835; BC200706183 at [24]–[29] per White J (rejecting a ground based on the absence of an affidavit accompanying the demand).

Later affidavits cannot be relied upon to identify a new ground for contending that the debt is genuinely disputed or raise a genuine offsetting claim. However, it is open to an applicant to supplement its initial affidavits by supplementary evidence relevant to an area of controversy which has been identified in the initial affidavits: Graywinter Properties Pty Ltd v Gas & Fuel Corp Superannuation Fund (1996) 70 FCR 452; 21 ACSR 581; BC9604587 ; Energy Equity Corp Ltd v Sinedie Pty Ltd (2001) 166 FLR 179 at 185; [2001] WASCA 419; BC200108161 ; Process Machinery Australia Pty Ltd (t/as DCL Engineering) v ACN 057 260 590 [2002] NSWSC 45; BC200200222 at [21]–[22] per Barrett J; Hills Motorway Ltd v UBS AG [2005] NSWSC 1086; BC200508993 at [22]–[36] per White J.

However a ground of dispute that has not been adequately raised in the required supporting affidavit, may be relied on if it is probative of the likelihood of substantial injustice, within the meaning of s 459J(1)(a) , if the demand is not set aside: Tablecloths.com.au Pty Ltd v Forbes (Aust) Pty Ltd [2005] NSWSC 1343; BC200511138 at [11] per Palmer J (obiter) (misdescription of the debt in the demand); LSI Australia Pty Ltd v LSI Holdings Ltd [2007] NSWSC 1406; BC200711058 at [60]–[64] per Austin J (debt vaguely described in the demand).
Legislation cited in [15,115.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 459G, s 459J, s 9.

In an application under Corporations Act 2001 s 459G , the court may also set aside the demand if it is satisfied that a defect in the demand will cause substantial injustice unless the demand is set aside, or if there is some other reason why the demand should be set aside: s 459J . “Defect” in relation to a statutory demand includes:
an irregularity
a misstatement of an amount or total;
a misdescription of a debt or other matter; and
a misdescription of a person or entity: Corporations Act 2001 s 9 .

According to its ordinary usage a “defect” means a lack or absence of something necessary or essential for completeness; a shortcoming or deficiency; an imperfection. A defect may be either major or minor: Topfelt Pty Ltd v State Bank of New South Wales Ltd (1993) 47 FCR 226 at 237; 120 ALR 155 per Lockhart J.

It is rare that deficiencies in the form of demands are so fundamental that the demands are incapable of assuming the description of statutory demands: cf Grace Consulting Pty Ltd v Bourke Constructions Pty Ltd (2005) 54 ACSR 677; [2005] NSWSC 836; BC200506194 per Young CJ in Eq, 24 August 2005 at [13]–[14]. Types of matters held to have made a demand defective include: claiming continuing interest without specifying the amount of the interest, the rate at which it was to be paid or a daily figure with reference to the rate: Topfelt Pty Ltd v State Bank of New South Wales Ltd, above; omitting from the prescribed form the notes following the schedule: Kalamunda Meat Wholesalers Pty Ltd v Reg Russell & Sons Pty Ltd (1994) 51 FCR 446; 128 ALR 149; BC9405958 ; three separate creditors claiming a composite debt: First Line Distribution Pty Ltd v Whiley (1995) 18 ACSR 185; 13 ACLC 1216; BC9505407 ; failing to give a description of the debt sufficiently meaningful to permit the recipient to assess whether it was the subject of a genuine dispute: LSI Australia Pty Ltd v LSI Holdings Ltd; LSI Australia Pty Ltd v LSI Consulting Pty Ltd [2007] NSWSC 1406; BC200711058 at [28], [29] and [54] (demands set aside — debt described as "amount due owing and payable by the Debtor to the Creditor, being moneys lent to the Debtor by the Creditor: $(amount)" — the date of the loan was not identified).

Matters held not to be defects justifying the setting aside of a demand include: claiming less than the actual debt: Hills Motorway Ltd v UBS AG [2005] NSWSC 1086; BC200508993 at [14], [36] per White J; omission of required warning constituted defect in the demand — no injustice caused by defect and failure of all joint creditors to sign the demand did not constitute a defect: Randall Pty Ltd v Chepan Pty Ltd [2009] NSWSC 783; BC200907211 per White J (application to set aside demand dismissed); JSBG Developments Pty Ltd v Kozlowski [2010] NSWSC 97; BC201001199 at [14]–[16] per Palmer J (no evidence that absence of warning misled — demand not set aside).
Legislation cited in [15,115.45] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 459H.

The court must set aside the statutory demand if it is satisfied the existence of the debt is genuinely disputed: Corporations Act 2001 s 459H . The expression “genuine dispute” connotes a plausible contention requiring investigation, and raises much the same sort of considerations as the “serious question to be tried” criterion, which arises on an application for an interlocutory injunction or for the extension or removal of a caveat. The court is not required to embark upon an inquiry as to the credit of a witness or a deponent whose evidence is relied on as giving rise to the dispute. There is a clear difference between determining whether there is a genuine dispute and resolving the merits of such a dispute: Eyota Pty Ltd v Hanave Pty Ltd (1994) 12 ACSR 785 at 787; (1994) 12 ACLC 669; BC9402306 per McLelland CJ in Eq; Di Francesca Holdings Pty Ltd v Hatziplis Holdings Pty Ltd [2005] NSWSC 169; BC200501393 at [10] per White J. The test of “plausible contention requiring investigation” (and other expressions such as “real and not spurious”, applied in summary procedure cases where it is not expected that the court will embark on any extended inquiry), mean that the task faced by a company challenging a statutory demand on the “genuine dispute” ground is not a difficult or demanding one. The company will fail in that task only if it is found that its challenges are so devoid of substance that no further investigation is warranted.

The court does not engage in any form of balancing exercise between the strengths of competing contentions. If it sees any factor that, on rational grounds has a sufficient degree of cogency to be arguable, it must find that a genuine dispute exists, even where any case apparently available to be advanced against the company seems stronger: Solarite Air Conditioning Pty Ltd v York International Australia Pty Ltd [2002] NSWSC 411; BC200202362 at [23] per Barrett J; Condor Asset Management Ltd v Excelsior Eastern Ltd (2005) 56 ACSR 223, [2005] NSWSC 1139; BC200509536 at [46] per Barrett J; Di Francesca Holdings Pty Ltd v Hatziplis Holdings Pty Ltd [2005] NSWSC 169; BC200501393 at [10] per White J; Daleville Pty Ltd v Progressive Realty Property Marketing & Management Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 637; BC200604632 at [24] per Barrett J; Lumina (South Yarra) Pty Ltd v MK River Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 784; BC200606059 at [24] per Barrett J; Roluke Pty Ltd v Hennessy (t/as PJ Hennessy & Co) [2006] NSWSC 814; BC200606258 at [25] per Barrett J.

In determining whether there is a “genuine dispute”, the court ought not to embark upon an assessment of the credit of a particular witness: Roandale Holdings Pty Ltd v Long Nominees Pty Ltd [2009] NSWSC 945; BC200908299 at [23] per Barrett J (demand set aside — genuine dispute established), citing Spacorp Australia Pty Ltd v Myer Stores Ltd (2001) 19 ACLC 1270; [2001] VSCA 89; BC200103084 at [3] and [4] ; Eyota Pty Ltd v Hanave Pty Ltd (1994) 12 ACSR 785 at 787; BC9402306 . Despite that limitation, and the comparatively undemanding nature of the evidence required, the court should not surrender credulity to mere assertion. The court may consider that the evidence does not demonstrate a “genuine dispute” where it is equivocal, imprecise, inconsistent with undisputed contemporary documents or other statements by the same deponent, patently or inherently improbable or merely argumentative: Eyota Pty Ltd v Hanave Pty Ltd, above, (ACSR) at 787; see also: Re Morris Catering (Aust) Pty Ltd (1993) 11 ACSR 601 at 605; 11 ACLC 919; BC9303014 ; Kalamunda Meat Wholesalers Pty Ltd v Reg Russell & Sons Pty Ltd (1994) 51 FCR 446; 128 ALR 149; BC9405958 .

Where the company relies on an offsetting claim, the court must be satisfied that there is a serious question to be tried: Scanhill Pty Ltd v Century 21 Australasia Pty Ltd (1993) 47 FCR 451; 120 ALR 173 ; Kalamunda Meat Wholesalers Pty Ltd v Reg Russell & Sons Pty Ltd, above. Where there is a genuine dispute (or offsetting claim) the court either must set aside the demand if the amount, if any, left in dispute is less than the statutory minimum, or it may make an order varying the demand: Corporations Act 2001 s 459H .

An appeal does not establish a “genuine dispute” as to the existence of the judgment debt. The “debt” is established by the primary judgment. That judgment is binding until it is varied or set aside. Consequently, any ongoing dispute pending resolution of the appeal can only be analysed as a dispute about the correctness of the primary judgment — rather than about the existence of the debt: Scope Data Systems Pty Ltd v BDO Nelson Parkhil (2003) 199 ALR 56; [2003] NSWSC 137 at [20]; (pending appeal of a local court judgment did not affect existence of debt); Wilden Pty Ltd v Greenco Pty Ltd (1995) 13 ACLC 1039 (appeal judgment reserved — existence of debt unaffected); Barclays Australia (Finance) Ltd v Mike Gaffikin Marine Pty Ltd (1996) 21 ACSR 235 (appeal relating to costs assessment — existence of debt unaffected). If the enforcement of the debt has been stayed, that circumstance may itself provide a basis for the court to either stay or dismiss the winding up proceedings: see [15,115.12] .

heading.title: Disputes as to existence or enforceability of the debt

p.text: A dispute as to the existence or enforceability of the debt may provide a basis for holding that winding up proceedings are an abuse of process: L & D Audio Acoustics Pty Ltd v Pioneer Electronics Australia Pty Ltd (1982) 7 ACLR 180 at 183 (delay for commercial advantage in making known the existence of a counter-claim until after time on a statutory demand expired precluded a finding that winding up proceedings were an abuse of process). Enforceability in this regard refers not to a stay of execution but to circumstances which go to the core of the indebtedness as between the creditor and debtor where there has been an adjudication of the debt such as where a cause of action is not maintainable because of a limitation defence, or a real dispute as to the date the debt arose or as to whether there had been an acknowledgement so as to revive the cause of action relating to the debt: Australian Beverage Distributors Pty Ltd v Evans & Tate Premium Wines Pty Ltd, (2007) 69 NSWLR 374; 61 ACSR 441; [2007] NSWCA 57; BC200701811 at [36]–[39] .

heading.title: Discretion to stay or dismiss despite undisputable existence of debt

p.text: There is a distinct principle, commonly regarded as an instance of abuse of process, that permits a court to stay or dismiss winding up proceedings in appropriate circumstances: Fortuna Holdings Pty Ltd v Deputy Federal Cmr of Taxation [1978] VR 83; (1976) 2 ACLR 349 ; Re Jeff Reid Pty Ltd and the Companies Act (1980) 5 ACLR 28 ; Pacific Communication Rentals Pty Ltd v Walker (1993) 12 ACSR 287; BC9302257 ; Braams Group Pty Ltd v Miric (2002) 171 FLR 449; (2002) 44 ACSR 124; [2002] NSWCA 417; BC200208051 and State Bank of New South Wales v Tela (No 2) (2002) 188 ALR 702; [2002] NSWSC 20; BC200200109 per Barrett J. One such set of circumstances is where the application to wind up must fail, either as a matter of law or fact (eg, because of the absence of supporting evidence). Another set of circumstances is where, although the basic grounds for winding up have been (or are likely to be) established, the court is satisfied that there is a more suitable alternative for resolving the controversy between the parties: Australian Beverage Distributors Pty Ltd v Evans & Tate Premium Wines Pty Ltd, above at [51]–[57] citing Fortuna Holdings Pty Ltd v Deputy Federal Cmr of Taxation VR at 93 (no injunction granted on the facts); Re Jeff Reid Pty Ltd , above (proceedings on the petition stayed) and Pacific Communication Rentals Pty Ltd , above (injunction granted to prevent commencement of winding up proceedings). The court has a discretion to grant a temporary stay of proceedings until the entire question of indebtedness between disputing companies has been determined: Australian Beverage Distributors Pty Ltd v Evans & Tate Premium Wines Pty Ltd , above at [56]–[57] (outstanding stay of enforcement of judgment debt).

The nature of the determination as to whether there is a “genuine dispute” which is interlocutory and not a final determination as to whether there is a debt due is such that it is not appropriate to embark upon an enquiry as to the credit of a witness, or a deponent whose evidence is relied on as giving rise to the dispute: Roandale Holdings Pty Ltd v Long Nominees Pty Ltd [2009] NSWSC 945; BC200908299 at [23] per Barrett J (demand set aside — genuine dispute established), citing Spacorp Australia Pty Ltd v Myer Stores Ltd (2001) 19 ACLC 1270; [2001] VSCA 89; BC200103084 at [3] and [4] ; Eyota Pty Ltd v Hanave Pty Ltd (1994) 12 ACSR 785 at 787; BC9402306 .

A plaintiff who relies upon an offsetting claim to set aside a statutory demand in its entirety must adduce evidence showing a plausible and coherent basis for asserting a claim to a sum which, despite elements of uncertainty, can be seen to be greater than the amount of the debt which is the subject of the statutory demand: Elm Financial Services Pty Ltd v Macdougal [2004] NSWSC 560; BC200403857 at [19] ; Hills Motorway Ltd v UBS AG [2005] NSWSC 1086; BC200508993 at [37] per White J.
Legislation cited in [15,115.53] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 459J(1)(a).

Even if there is no genuine dispute about the particular debt, a statutory demand might still be set aside if there is either an offsetting claim, or a “defect” in the demand likely to cause “substantial injustice”: see Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) s 459J(1)(a) and Faji (Australia) Constructions Pty Ltd v AC Professional Accounting Pty Ltd [2009] NSWSC 180; BC200901706 (affidavit verifying the demand contained hearsay assertion).
Legislation cited in [15,115.55] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 459H.

An order in relation to a disputed claim or offsetting claim under s 459H may be made subject to conditions: Jesseron Holdings Pty Ltd v Middle East Trading Consultants Pty Ltd (No 2) (1994) 122 ALR 717; 13 ACSR 787; BC9402621 (the court ordered that a statutory demand be set aside conditional upon a specified sum being paid to the creditor within 28 days).
Legislation cited in [15,115.60] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 49.4.

An order setting aside a statutory demand is a final order: A-Pak Plastics Pty Ltd v Merhone Pty Ltd (1995) 17 ACSR 176; 120 FLR 227; BC9504730 (NSWCA). An order refusing to set aside a statutory demand is probably also a final order. The fact that, at the same time, an order is made extending time for compliance with the statutory demand does not change the quality of the dismissal order, nor can the order extending time be regarded in its own right as an interlocutory order: Infact Consulting Pty Ltd v Kyle House Pty Ltd [2005] NSWSC 1092; BC200508856 at [11] per Barrett J. Appeals from decisions of an Associate Judge to dismiss an application for an order setting aside the statutory demand and to make an order extending time for compliance must be made to the Court of Appeal and not to the court constituted by a single judge: UCPR r 49.4 ; [SCA s 104] ; [SCR Pt 60.17.1] : Infact Consulting Pty Ltd v Kyle House Pty Ltd, above[2005] NSWSC 1092; BC200508856 at [3]–[13] per Barrett J (appeal to a single judge dismissed as incompetent).

Costs will normally follow the event. Howeve,r the court may also order indemnity costs in an appropriate case – such as where a creditor has a creditor has used the statutory demand procedure to force payment of a genuinely contested debt (eg, Polaroid Australia Pty Ltd v Minicomp Pty Ltd (1997) 16 ACLC 529; BC9707635; Austrac Rail Pty Ltd v Hunter Premium Funding Ltd [2001] NSWSC 654; BC200104352 ; CGI Information Systems and Management Consultants Pty Ltd v APRA Consulting Pty Ltd (2003) 47 ACSR 100; [2003] NSWSC 728; BC200304391 ). The reconciliation of these two general principles relating to the exercise of the costs discretion will sometimes require an impressionistic assessment — given the nature of the “genuine dispute” criterion: see [15,115.45] . The court must be careful not to seem to stifle, by indemnity costs orders, proper attempts by a defendant to put the plaintiff to proof of its claim of genuine dispute, offsetting claim, defect or other matter said to warrant setting aside of the statutory demand: Saferack Pty Ltd v Marketing Heads Australia Pty Ltd [2007] NSWSC 1317; BC200709973 at [14] per Barrett J.

However, the view has also been expressed that the mere claim that the defendant ought to have been aware that a genuine dispute exists is not a sufficient basis to warrant an indemnity costs order, particularly where there is no evidence to suggest that the Defendant's purpose in issuing its statutory demand was other than to secure payment of its debt or to test the genuineness of the alleged dispute. A defendant may put a plaintiff to appropriate proof that a genuine dispute exists and see what evidentiary material the plaintiff is able to marshal in support of its assertions: Redglove Holdings Pty Ltd v GNE & Associates Pty Ltd (2001) 165 FLR 72; (2002) 20 ACLC 304; [2001] NSWSC 867; BC200105995 at [32] per Palmer J; Club Marconi of Bossley Park v AVR Services NSW Pty Ltd [2002] NSWSC 584; BC200203662 at [24] per Palmer J; Grass Manufacturers Pty Ltd v Sraennik Pty Ltd [2003] NSWSC 95; BC200300470 at [30] per Palmer J. Where a demand is found to be affected by defects of lack of clarity and lack of information identified in a prompt complaint by the applicant, an indemnity costs order has been held to be appropriate: Condor Asset Management Ltd v Excelsior Eastern Ltd — Costs [2006] NSWSC 510; BC20063749 at [7] per Barrett J.

Indemnity costs will also be awarded where there is “some relevant delinquency on the part of the unsuccessful party”: Saferack Pty Ltd v Marketing Heads Australia Pty Ltd [2007] NSWSC 1317; BC200709973 at [12]–[15] per Barrett J (indemnity costs awarded where the defendant sought to take advantage of circumstances rendering doubtful or obscure the situation of its registered office).
Subject to rule 5.4 , an affidavit that is to be made by a creditor may be made:

if the creditor is a corporation — by a director, secretary, or other principal officer of the corporation, or by a person employed by the corporation who is authorised to make the affidavit on its behalf; or
if the creditor is a company to which a liquidator, provisional liquidator, receiver, administrator or controller has been appointed — by that person; or
in any other case — by the creditor or a person authorised by the creditor to make the affidavit on behalf of the creditor.
An affidavit must be in a form that complies with:
the rules of the Court; or
the rules of the Supreme Court of the State (if any) or Territory (if any) where the affidavit was sworn or affirmed; or
the rules of the Federal Court of Australia.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,130] r 2.7 Service of originating process or interlocutory process and supporting affidavit

leg:heading.title: Service of originating process or interlocutory process and supporting affidavit

p.text: As soon as practicable after filing an originating process and, in any case, at least 5 days before the date fixed for hearing, the plaintiff must serve a copy of the originating process and any supporting affidavit on:
each defendant (if any) to the proceeding; and
if the corporation to which the proceeding relates is not a party to the proceeding — the corporation.

As soon as practicable after filing an interlocutory process and, in any case, at least 3 days before the date fixed for hearing, the applicant must serve a copy of the interlocutory process and any supporting affidavit on:
each respondent (if any) to the application in the interlocutory process; and
if the corporation to which the application in the interlocutory process relates is not a party to the interlocutory application — the corporation.
[subr (2) am Gaz 48 of 5 April 2007 p 2118, effective 5 April 2007]
Legislation cited in [15,130.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 ss 109X, 601CX.

Specific provisions concerning the service of documents on companies are contained in the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) ss 109X and 601CX . A document may be served on a company by leaving it at, or by sending it by post to, the registered office of the company. Service may also be effected by delivering a copy of the document personally to a director of the company who resides in Australia or its territories: see [10.22.5] .Where documents have been sent by post the refusal of the defendant to receive the documents will not preclude service from being effective: Dennis v Fodare Pty Ltd [2007] NSWSC 180; BC200701289 per Barrett J (envelope was returned to the plaintiff by the post office bearing a post office sticker saying, “Return to sender” and giving as an explanation “Refused”).

level.toc-caption: [15,130.10] Applications to set aside a statutory demand

p.text: Legislation cited in [15,130.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 109X, s 459G, s 459G(2), s 459G(3), s 459G(3)(b).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 10.20(2)(a).
(CTH) Acts Interpretation Act 1901 s28A.

heading.title: Applications to set aside a statutory demand

p.text: An application to set aside a statutory demand must be “made” within 21 days after the demand is served: s 459G(2) Corporations Act 2001 (Cth). Section 459G(3) provides that an application is made in accordance with the section only if, within those 21 days (a) an affidavit supporting the application is filed with the court and a copy of the application, and (b) a copy of the supporting affidavit, are served on the person who served the demand on the company. If the company purports to make its application after the expiry of the time period, the court has no jurisdiction to deal with it: David Grant & Co Pty Ltd v Westpac Banking Corp (1995) 184 CLR 265; 131 ALR 353; [1995] HCA 43 .

Filing is essential and filing of the application (originating process) must occur before service: Austar Finance Group Pty Ltd v Campbell [2007] NSWSC 1493; BC200711464 per Austin J at [24]–[29]. Filing of the supporting affidavit must occur within the 21 days: Pearlburst Pty Ltd v Summers Resort Group Pty Ltd; Landmark Leisure Group Pty Ltd v Summers Resort Group Pty Ltd [2007] NSWSC 1126 at [5]–[14]; BC200708731 . However, it seems that filing of the affidavit (within that 21 days) need not occur before the service of a copy of the affidavit. An unfiled affidavit served before the filing of the application can still be a "supporting affidavit" for the purposes of s 459G(3)(b) , though it must be the same affidavit that is eventually filed: Austar Finance Group Pty Ltd v Campbell [2007] NSWSC 1493; BC200711464 per Austin J at [24]–[31] (application transmitted by facsimile before filing and then in a broken facsimile after filing, not seen until outside the 21 day period — application also transmitted by email, not seen until after the 21 day period — held application not properly served).

The application and affidavit are not required to be served together (though often that would be the case): Austar Finance Group Pty Ltd v Campbell [2007] NSWSC 1493; BC200711464 per Austin J at [24]. In the case of service of an originating process in proceedings brought under the Corporations Act, including proceedings brought under s 459G , some statutory provisions override the general requirement for personal service under UCPR 10.20(2)(a) , to the extent that they permit service by other means: Austar Finance Group Pty Ltd v Campbell [2007] NSWSC 1493; BC200711464 per Austin J at [40]. The service of documents on a company or a director or secretary of a company is dealt with in s 109X Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) (see [15,130.5] ). Informal service (proof that the document had actually been received in a readable form by the person to be served) may be relied upon even though the requirements concerning service by post under s 109X are not satisfied: Pearlburst Pty Ltd v Summers Resort Group Pty Ltd; Landmark Leisure Group Pty Ltd v Summers Resort Group Pty Ltd [2007] NSWSC 1126 at [22]–[30]; BC200708731 . In the case of service on a natural person, service may be effected by delivering it to the person personally; or by leaving it at, or by sending it by pre-paid post to, the address of the place of residence or business of the person last known to the person serving the document: s28A Acts Interpretation Act 1901 (Cth). Section 28A is facultative, and does not exclude the possibility that service may validly be effected in some other way under any other law, including an applicable State law. Since personal service of an originating process is generally required under the UCPR, s28A effectively defines the circumstances in which something less than personal service of an originating process in proceedings under the Corporations Act is permissible: Austar Finance Group Pty Ltd v Campbell [2007] NSWSC 1493; BC200711464 per Austin J at [43] (application not properly served). Electronic transmission, whether by facsimile or email, cannot constitute service for the purposes of s 459G(3) unless either: it is shown that the documents electronically transmitted have actually been received in a readable form by the person to be served; or the case falls within any special exception permitted by rules of court: Austar Finance Group Pty Ltd v Campbell [2007] NSWSC 1493; BC200711464 per Austin J at [49]–[56].

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,135] r 2.8 Notice of certain applications to be given to ASIC

leg:heading.title: Notice of certain applications to be given to ASIC

p.text: This rule has effect in addition to the requirements of the Corporations Act that, in relation to a proceeding, particular documents are to be served on ASIC or notice of particular matters is to be given to ASIC.
[subr (1) am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004 ; Gaz 53 of 16 May 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 16 May 2008]
This rule does not apply to a person making an application if the person is ASIC or a person authorised by ASIC.
[subr (2) am Gaz 53 of 16 May 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 16 May 2008]

Unless the Court otherwise orders, if a person makes an application under a provision of the Corporations Act mentioned in column 2 of an item of the following table, the person must serve on ASIC, a reasonable time before the hearing of the application, a copy of the originating process, or interlocutory process, and supporting affidavit in respect of the application.

row.entry: For the release of a liquidator of a company and the deregistration of the company
For the stay or termination of a winding up
For the deregistration of a company
For an inquiry into the conduct of a liquidator
To reinstate the registration of a company
To restore the name of an Australian body to the register
To restore the name of a foreign company to the register
For relief from liability for contravention of a civil penalty provision

p.text: [subr (3) subst Gaz 168 of 22 December 2000 p 13608 ; am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004 ; Gaz 53 of 16 May 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[3]–[4], effective 16 May 2008]
[heading am Gaz 53 of 16 May 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 16 May 2008]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,140] r 2.9 Notice of appearance (Corporations Act s 465C) — Form 4

leg:heading.title: Notice of appearance (Corporations Act s 465C ) — Form 4

p.text: A person who intends to appear before the Court at the hearing of an application must, before appearing:
file:
a notice of appearance in accordance with Form 4 ; and
if appropriate — an affidavit stating any facts on which the person intends to rely; and
serve on the plaintiff a copy of the notice of appearance and any affidavit not later than:
if the person is named in an originating process — 3 days before the date fixed for hearing; or
if the person is named in an interlocutory process — 1 day before the date fixed for hearing.

If the person intends to appear before the Court to oppose an application for winding up, the person may include in the notice of appearance the notice of the grounds on which the person opposes the application required by section 465C of the Corporations Act.
[subr (2) am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
The period prescribed for filing and serving the notice and affidavit required by section 465C of the Corporations Act is the period mentioned in subparagraph (1)(b)(i) .

Under section 465C of the Corporations Act, a person may not, without the leave of the Court, oppose an application for winding up unless, within the period prescribed by the rules (see subrule (3) of this rule), the person has filed, and served on the plaintiff, notice of the grounds on which the person opposes the application and an affidavit verifying the matters stated in the notice.
[subr (3) am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
[r 2.9 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,145] r 2.10 Intervention in proceeding by ASIC (Corporations Act s 1330) — Form 5

leg:heading.title: Intervention in proceeding by ASIC (Corporations Act s 1330 ) — Form 5

p.text: If ASIC intends to intervene in a proceeding, ASIC must file a notice of intervention in accordance with Form 5 .
[subr (1) am Gaz 53 of 16 May 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 16 May 2008]

Not later than 3 days before the date fixed for the hearing at which ASIC intends to appear in the proceeding, ASIC must serve a copy of the notice, and any affidavit on which it intends to rely, on the plaintiff and on any other party to the proceeding.
[subr (2) am Gaz 53 of 16 May 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 16 May 2008]
[r 2.10 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004 ; Gaz 53 of 16 May 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[5], effective 16 May 2008]
[heading am Gaz 53 of 16 May 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[5], effective 16 May 2008]

If a rule requires a notice in relation to a body to be published in accordance with this rule, the notice must be published once in a daily newspaper circulating generally in the State or Territory where the body has its principal, or last known, place of business.

Under the Corporations Act , certain notices may also be required to be published in the Gazette. Nothing in this rule is intended to affect the operation of any provision of the Corporations Act that requires publication of a notice in the Gazette.

The originating process should be served on the company before it is advertised. In some circumstances advertising the summons before service on the company, may constitute an abuse of process justifying dismissal of the summons: see Paterson v Hampton Interiors (1989) 7 ACLC 904; BC8902068 ; however merely unintentional premature advertising may be excused: Melcann Ltd v Marmlon Holdings Pty Ltd (1991) 4 ACSR 736; 9 ACLC 678; BC9102038 .
This rule applies in relation to any matter published in connection with a proceeding.
Unless these Rules otherwise provide, or the Court otherwise orders, the person responsible for the publication of the matter, or the person's legal practitioner, must file:
an affidavit made by the person, or the person's legal practitioner, that states the date of publication and to which is annexed or exhibited a copy of the published matter; or
a memorandum signed by the person, or the person's legal practitioner, that states the date of publication and refers to and annexes a copy of the published matter.
The affidavit or memorandum is prima facie evidence that the publication took place on the date and otherwise as stated in the affidavit or memorandum.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,160] r 2.13 Leave to creditor, contributory or officer to be heard

leg:heading.title: Leave to creditor, contributory or officer to be heard

p.text: The Court may grant leave to any person who is, or who claims to be:
a creditor, contributory or officer of a corporation; or
an officer of a creditor, or contributory, of a corporation; or
any other interested person;
to be heard in a proceeding without becoming a party to the proceeding.
[subr (1) am Gaz 168 of 22 December 2000 p 13608]

If the Court considers that the attendance of a person to whom leave has been granted under subrule (1) has resulted in additional costs for any party, or the corporation, which should be borne by the person to whom leave was granted, the Court may:
direct that the person pay the costs; and
order that the person not be heard further in the proceeding until the costs are paid or secured to the Court's satisfaction.
The Court may order that a person who is, or who claims to be, a creditor, contributory or officer of a corporation be added as a defendant to the proceeding.
The Court may grant leave to a person under subrule (1) , or order that a person be added as a defendant to a proceeding under subrule (3) :
on application by the person or a party to the proceeding; or
on the Court's own initiative.
The Court may:

appoint a creditor or contributory to represent all or any class of the creditors or contributories on any question, or in relation to any proceeding, before the Court, at the expense of the corporation; and
remove any person so appointed.

There is no inherent power in the Supreme Court to permit intervention in proceedings: Onefone Australia Pty Ltd v One.Tel Ltd; Weston v Publishing and Broadcasting Ltd [2007] NSWSC 1320; BC200709976 at [8] per Barrett J citing Corporate Affairs Commission v Bradley [1974] 1 NSWLR 391 (defendants in unserved originating process refused leave to be heard on an application for extension of the time for which the process remains valid for service). Leave may be granted to a creditor to be heard where the interest of the creditor arises from other proceedings in which the status or quantum of the creditor's claim is in issue: Spedley Securities Ltd (in liq) v Bank of New Zealand (1990) 3 ACSR 366; 9 ACLC 124; BC9001710 . The court may of its own motion make an order under r2.13 allowing a director the opportunity to present material in support of a company's case: Commonwealth Bank of Australia v Western D Engineering Co Pty Ltd (NSWSC, McLelland CJ in Eq, 1548/93, 8 August 1994, unreported, BC9402922). An order granting leave might be implied from the circumstances of the hearing: Chalmers v Redwood Anti-Ageing Pty Ltd (2007) 215 FLR 8; [2007] NSWSC 1186; BC200709045 at [13] (a creditor who filed a notice of appearance and was heard was impliedly given leave). The fact that a supporting creditor who is not a party is given leave to appear at first instance does not necessarily entitle the creditor to appear on an appeal: Chalmers v Redwood Anti-Ageing Pty Ltd (2007) 215 FLR 8; [2007] NSWSC 1186; BC200709045 at [27] (held creditor not entitled to be heard on appeal).
Legislation cited in [15,160.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 2.13.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 [s 98.25].
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 556(1)(a).

A person who elects to participate in proceedings on the UCPR r 2.13 basis is not susceptible to a costs order in the ordinary course. Such a person could be ordered to pay costs only in the special circumstances (and to the limited extent) referred to in r 2.13(2) or by reference to the general principles concerning the award of costs against non-parties (see [s 98.25] ). Likewise, an award of costs in favour of such a person is exceptional: Re HIH Casualty and General Insurance Ltd [2006] NSWSC 6; BC200600160 , applying Re Pan Pharmaceuticals Ltd; Selim v McGrath (2004) 48 ACSR 681; [2004] NSWSC 129; BC200400814 (non-party granted leave to be heard sought costs — no “very special factor” shown — application refused); Grocon Constructors Pty Ltd v Kimberley Securities Ltd [2009] NSWSC 691; BC200906359 at [3], [6] per Barrett J (tendered relevant evidence, being heard in oral argument “on a key point” and produced the consent of the liquidators who were ultimately appointed by the court held not to be special factors — no costs order made). Exceptionally, costs orders have been made in favour of those granted leave. See for example Re HIH Casualty and General Insurance Ltd [2006] NSWSC 6; BC200600160 per Barrett J (effectively one set of costs ordered in favour of parties granted leave to be heard — separate submissions that where highly relevant to the task of the Court in reaching its decision); Re Wan Ze Property Development (Aust) Pty Ltd (In liq) [2013] NSWSC 189; BC201301461 at [115]–[116] per Black J (parties granted leave to be heard were awarded costs — exceptional circumstances).

The costs of an intervening creditor on a winding up application may be ordered to be paid under Corporations Act 2001 s 556(1)(a) as part of the costs of the winding up: Signature Resorts Pty Ltd v DHD Constructions Pty Ltd (1995) 18 ACSR 627 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,165] r 2.14 Inquiry in relation to corporation's debts etc

leg:heading.title: Inquiry in relation to corporation's debts etc

p.text: The Court may direct an inquiry in relation to the debts, claims or liabilities, or a class of debts, claims or liabilities, of or affecting a corporation to which a proceeding relates.

Where the court directs an enquiry, the settlement of a list of creditors has been held to be mandatory: Re Ballarat Land Mortgage & Agency Co Ltd (1897) 3 ALR 216 ; Re Motor Investments Ltd [1931] VLR 301; (1931) 37 ALR 273 . However preparation of a list has been dispensed with in certain circumstances: Re Hepburn Mineral Springs Hotel Ltd [1932] VLR 483; [1932] ALR 421 (where creditors consented to the reduction of capital); Re A Lesser & Co Pty Ltd [1929] VLR 316; (1929) 35 ALR 265 (where the only liabilities were current trade liabilities); Re Hodder & Trolley Ltd [1975] 2 NZLR 395 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,170] r 2.15 Meetings ordered by the Court

p.text: Subject to the Corporations Act, these Rules and any direction of the Court to the contrary, regulations 5.6.11 to 5.6.36A of the Corporations Regulations apply to meetings ordered by the Court.
[r 2.15 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004 ; Gaz 53 of 16 May 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[6], effective 16 May 2008]
